instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power. Client says that it just stoped working.

With the board alone at the bench, the ampmeter just stays black, and on the bench PSU it pulls 5.06V.

<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC1</SIGNAL>/2 and <SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC1</SIGNAL>/2 diode reading seams to be ok (0.594).

<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS_F</SIGNAL> has 0.522V on F3000, and 0.184  diode reading

<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS_F</SIGNAL> has 5.06V on F3010, and 0.184  diode reading

 Should i  replace <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Be aware, CC1/2 signals don't go directly to J3300.
Check diode mode on the _CONN side of them.
Also inspect USB-C terminals for corrosion.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I can't see any corrosion on USB-C terminals, and all _CONN caps have 0.191 on diode reading

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings on other J3300 pins with good board.
Also do the same for <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> LDOs.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
All readings were normal, and after a close look, i realize that <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> had a small burnt mark on it and so i replaced it.

Now it powers on, but it was not charging, and stoped consuming any amperage after a while. The ampmeter stayed black again, but it worked while on battery.

However, after a PR Reset it started to pull 20V again,  2.98A and is charging the battery again.

Waht should i check to make sure that it is ok?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
